content.title: Find the equation of the quadratic with graph

questions.label: a
questions.description: Concave down parabola with x-intercepts at -1 and 3, passing through (0, 3)
solution: Since the x-intercepts are $-1$ and $3$, $y = a(x+1)(x-3)$.
The graph is concave down, so $a < 0$.

questions.label: b
questions.description: Concave up parabola touching x-axis at x = 2, passing through (0, 8)
solution: The graph touches the x-axis at $x = 2$, so $y = a(x-2)^2$.
The graph is concave up, so $a > 0$.

content.title: Find the equation of the quadratic with graph
content.description: Concave down parabola with vertex at (1, 16), x-intercepts at -2 and 4
solution: The axis of symmetry $x = 1$ lies midway between the x-intercepts.
$\therefore$ the quadratic has the form $y = a(x+2)(x-4)$ where $a < 0$.

content.title: Find the equation of the quadratic whose graph cuts the x-axis at 4 and -3, and which passes through the point (2, -20). Give your answer in the form $y = ax^2 + bx + c$.
solution: Since the x-intercepts are 4 and $-3$, the quadratic has the form $y = a(x-4)(x+3)$, $a \neq 0$.

content.title: Quadratic inequality
content.content: A quadratic inequality can be written in either the form $ax^2 + bx + c \geqslant 0$ or $ax^2 + bx + c > 0$ where $a \neq 0$.

content.title: Sign Diagrams
content.content: A sign diagram is a number line which indicates the values of $x$ for which a function is negative, zero, positive, or undefined.
components: a horizontal line which represents the $x$-axis
positive (+) and negative (-) signs indicating where the graph is above and below the $x$-axis respectively
the zeros of the function, which are the $x$-intercepts of its graph

examples.description: Upward parabola with zeros at -2 and 1
Upward parabola with vertex above x-axis (no real zeros)
Downward parabola touching x-axis at x = 1

content.title: Sign change rules
rules: A sign change occurs about a zero of the function for single linear factors such as $(x+2)$ and $(x-1)$. This indicates cutting of the $x$-axis.
No sign change occurs about a zero of the function for squared linear factors such as $(x-1)^2$. This indicates touching of the $x$-axis.
general_rules: when a linear factor has an odd power there is a change of sign about that zero
when a linear factor has an even power there is no sign change about that zero

content.title: Quadratic Inequalities
content.content: To solve quadratic inequalities we use the following procedure:
steps: Make the RHS zero by shifting all terms to the LHS.
Draw a sign diagram for the LHS.
Determine the values required from the sign diagram.

content.title: Solve for $x$:

questions.label: a
solution: Sign diagram of LHS: + for $x < -2$, - for $-2 < x < \frac{1}{3}$, + for $x > \frac{1}{3}$

questions.label: b
solution: Sign diagram of LHS: + for all $x$
So, the inequality is not true for any real $x$.

content.title: Find the value(s) of $k$ for which the function $y = kx^2 + (k+3)x - 1$:

questions.label: a
questions.instruction: cuts the x-axis twice
solution: So, $\Delta$ has sign diagram: + for $k < -9$, - for $-9 < k < -1$, + for $k > -1$
The graph cuts the x-axis twice if $\Delta > 0$

questions.label: b
questions.instruction: touches the x-axis
questions.solution: The graph touches the x-axis if $\Delta = 0$ $\therefore k = -9$ or $k = -1$.

questions.label: c
questions.instruction: misses the x-axis
questions.solution: The graph misses the x-axis if $\Delta < 0$ $\therefore -9 < k < -1$.

content.note: The discriminant $\Delta$ is a quadratic in $k$, so we must solve a quadratic inequality.
